Scheme 1 Synthesis of the [SOS]-type ligands La–c, the Fe(II) complexes 1a–c and the Fe(III) complexes 2a–c. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Formation of the anionic species [2a-Br3]−. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 Proposed structure for the Fe(II) 1a–c and Fe(III) 2a–c complexes. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Effect of the co-catalyst type and loading (a) and temperature (b) on the catalytic activity of 1a in the cycloaddition of CO2 to HO (Table S1). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 UV–vis spectra of complexes 1a (a) and 2a (b) before (black) and after the addition of 50 equivalents of Py (blue) or 5 equivalents of TBAB (red) (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides promoted by bis-thioether-phenolate Fe(II) and Fe(III) complexes Francesco Della Monica Mattia Leone Antonio Buonerba Alfonso Grassi Stefano Milione Carmine Capacchione ⁎ Dipartimento di Chimica e Biologia “Adolfo Zambelli”- Università degli Studi di Salerno, Via Giovanni Paolo II, 84084 Fisciano, SA, Italy Dipartimento di Chimica e Biologia “Adolfo Zambelli”- Università degli Studi di Salerno Via Giovanni Paolo II Fisciano SA 84084 Italy ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The synthesis and characterization of three new bis-thioether-phenolate monoanionic tridentate [SOS]-type ligands, and the synthesis of the corresponding Fe(II) and Fe(III) complexes are reported. Their application, in combination with tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB), as catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 to a number of monosubstituted epoxides and cyclohexene oxide was investigated. For example, epichlorohydrin is converted in the corresponding cyclic carbonate, with a turnover frequency of 155 h−1 (0.1 mol% of iron, 0.5 mol% of TBAB, 10 bar of CO2). With the aim to obtain further information about the catalyst structure-activity relationship and the reaction mechanism, the reaction between the catalyst precursors and TBAB was investigated, suggesting the formation of an anionic metallate species in the case of the Fe(III) complexes that is supposed to be true catalyst. A mechanistic scenario explaining the different behaviour of the Fe(II) and Fe(III) complexes is proposed. Keywords Carbon dioxide Epoxide Cyclic organic carbonate Iron Homogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide concentration has very recently pushed beyond 400 ppm in the atmosphere [1]. Notwithstanding this is not to be considered a tipping point, the inexorable rise of this value over the past decades witness the incapability of the humankind to sensibly reduce the emission of this greenhouse gas. In the battle against the CO2 emissions, there is a growing body of evidence that we do not have a single silver bullet to invert this tendency, and we rather need a multilateral approach to reach the target of reducing the level of CO2, warranting a more sustainable development of our society [2,3]. Therefore, the implementation of less energy consuming industrial processes and the use of renewable resource, should be flanked by technology aimed to recover the CO2 emitted in the combustion of coal or hydrocarbons [4]. In this scenario the possible utilization of carbon dioxide as a single carbon chemical feedstock for the production of value added products such as fuels, chemicals and materials became an active task of research [5]. This approach should face with both the thermodynamic stability of CO2 and its kinetic inertness [6,7]. As for other industrial relevant processes, also in this case the key to access to the wide chemistry of carbon dioxide is represented by the development of efficient catalytic systems [8]. In this ambit the coupling of CO2 with epoxides to give cyclic organic carbonates (COCs) is one of the most studied reaction for the importance of the resulting products [9,10]. As a matter of fact, COCs have many applications as highly boiling polar solvents, electrolytes in lithium–ion batteries and chemical intermediates in the synthesis of other industrially relevant products. The catalytic systems for the synthesis of COCs are generally based on the combination of a metal complex with a nucleophile (quaternary ammonium salts and phosphonium salts) as co-catalyst [11]. Notably, the most studied and active catalytic systems are based on transition and main group metals such as aluminium [12,13], cobalt [14], chromium [15], zinc [16–19], magnesium [20] or lanthanides [21]. Some of these metals have risen health and environmental concerns, and in some cases have been recently defined as endangered elements (i.e. metals that will be not available in the next future at affordable price) [22]. Iron is widely recognized as a cost effective and biocompatible metal but, notwithstanding the growing interest in the use of this metal in catalysis [23,24], the use of iron based catalysts for the formation of cyclic carbonates from CO2 has received limited attention [25–32]. Recently, we have reported on very efficient catalytic systems based on both dinuclear [33–35] and mononuclear [36] Fe(III) complexes, coordinated by bis-thioether-tri-phenolate, and bis-thioether-di-pehonolate [OSSO]-type ligands, respectively. In particular, these complexes have shown to be high active in the synthesis of various COCs from terminal and internal epoxides, when activated by tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB). Moreover, mechanistic studies trough DFT calculations for the dinuclear system [35], and combined kinetic measurements-DFT investigation for the mononuclear [36], evidenced not only the crucial role of the hemilabile Fe–S bond in the catalytic activity but also that in the first case only one metal centre is active in the catalytic cycle, while in the second case the reaction proceeds through a bimetallic ring opening of the epoxide. The most of the Fe-based catalytic systems for the production of COCs contains the metal in the oxidation state +3, with few exceptions [37,38], and, to the best of our knowledge, the evaluation of the role of the oxidation state with the metal centre supported by the same ligand has never been investigated specifically. Consequently, our attention has focussed on the synthesis of iron-based complexes supported by ligands containing sulphur atoms in the backbone, and capable to generate Fe(II) and Fe(III) with the same coordination environment. In particular, in this work we report on the synthesis and complete characterization of three new monoanionic bis-thioether-phenolate [SOS]-type ligands and their corresponding iron(II) and iron(III) complexes. The use of these complexes as catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides was investigated with the aim to evaluate the possible role of the oxidation state of the iron centre on the behaviour of the catalytic system. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and methods All manipulation involving air- and/or moisture-sensitive compounds were performed under nitrogen atmosphere using standard Schlenk technique and a MBraun glovebox. Toluene (99.5%; Sigma-Aldrich) and THF (99%; Sigma-Aldrich) were used as received or refluxed for 48 h over sodium or sodium ketyls and distilled before use for moisture- and oxygen-sensitive reactions. All other reagents were used as received (TCI or Sigma-Aldrich) or distilled under reduced pressure over calcium hydride. Deuterated solvents were purchased from Euriso-Top or Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. NMR spectra were collected on Bruker Avance spectrometers (600, 400, 300 or 250 MHz for 1H): the chemical shifts were referenced to tetramethylsilane (TMS) as external reference using the residual protio signal of the deuterated solvents. Measurements of effective magnetic moments were performed on a Bruker Avance 400 MHz spectrometer at 25 °C in CD2Cl2 using a 5 mm Wilmad coaxial insert NMR tube. Solutions of the iron complexes 1a-c,and 2a-c in toluene-d8 with 1% (v/v) of TMS were prepared under nitrogen atmosphere. The effective magnetic moment (μeff) was calculated from μeff = 8χgMWT, where χg (cm3 ∙ g−1) is the corrected molar susceptibility derived from χg = 3Δf/4πfoCMW + χo. Δf is the shift in frequency (Hz) of the residual protio signal of the solvent in the presence of the complex from the value of the pure solvent, C and MW are respectively the concentration (mol ∙ cm−3) and the molecular weight of the complex (g ∙ mol−1), fo is the operating frequency of the spectrometer (Hz), and χo is the mass susceptibility of the pure solvent (−0.733 ∙ 10−6 cm3 ∙ g−1 for CD2Cl2). 4π/3 is the shape factor for a cylindrical sample in a superconducting magnet. Elemental analysis was performed on a CHNS Thermo Scientific Flash EA 1112 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. High resolution Electrospray Ionization Fourier Transform Ion Cyclotron Resonance Mass Spectrometry (ESI FT-ICR MS) measurements were performed on a Bruker Solaris XR instrument. UV–vis spectra were collected on a PerkinElmer Lambda EZ 201 spectrophotometer. 2.2 Synthesis of the pro-ligand 4-tert-butyl-2,6-((2,6-dimethyl)thiophenyl)-phenol La A 100 mL flask equipped with a magnetic stirring bar was charged, under nitrogen atmosphere, with 2.46 g (18.0 mmol) of 2,6-dimethylbenzenthiol and THF (30 mL). A solution of tBuONa (1.72 g, 18.0 mmol) in THF (15 mL) was added to the flask dropwise. After 15 min, a solution of 2,6-bis-bromomethyl-4-tert-butyl-phenol (3.05 g, 9.0 mmol) in THF (30 mL) was added dropwise and the reaction was kept at room temperature overnight. The solvent was distilled off, water was added until dissolution of NaBr by-product and the aqueous phase extracted twice with methylene chloride. The combined organic phases were dried with Na2SO4. After evaporation of the solvent, the pure product was obtained by crystallization from acetonitrile solution at −20 °C. Yield: 2.80 g, 69%. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 1.01 (s, 9H, −C(CH3)3), 2.41 (s, 12H, −CH3), 3.85 (s, 4H, −CH2-), 5.98 (s, 1H, −OH), 6.55 (s, 2H, Ar-H), 7.02–7.12 (overlapped, 6H, Ar-H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 22.00, 31.29, 33.85, 35.40, 124.28, 126.59, 128.27, 128.64, 132.37, 142.80, 143.54, 150.32. Mass spectrum: 473.1949 m/z (MNa+, calc: 473.1943), 923.4006 m/z (M2Na+, calc. 923.3994). Elemental Analysis: calcd.(%) for C28H34OS2: C, 74.62; H, 7.60; S, 14.23; found: C, 74.65; H, 7.67; S, 14.12. 2.3 Synthesis of the pro-ligand 4-tert-butyl-2,6-((2,6-dichloro)thiophenyl)-phenol Lb The pro-ligand Lb was synthesized using the same procedure of La. The pure product was obtained by crystallization from pentane solution. Yield: 2.34 g, 80%. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD2Cl2): δ 1.07 (s, 9H, −C(CH3)3), 4.16 (s, 4H, −CH2−), 6.26 (s, 1H, −OH), 6.76 (s, 2H, Ar-H), 7.16 (t, 2H, J = 7.9 Hz, Ar-H), 7.34 (4H, 7.9 Hz, Ar-H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 31.34, 33.90, 35.38, 123.25, 127.10, 128.56, 130.20, 132.03, 141.87, 142.76, 151.07. Mass spectrum: 554.9744 m/z (MNa+, calc: 554.9728), 1086.9610 m/z (M2Na+, calc. 1086.9574). Elemental Analysis: calcd.(%) for C24H22Cl4OS2: C, 54.15; H, 4.17; S, 12.05; found: C, 54.17; H, 4.18; S, 11.98. 2.4 Synthesis of the pro-ligand 4-tert-butyl-2,6-((2,4,6-tri-iso-propyl)thiophenyl)-phenol Lc The pro-ligand Lc was synthesized using the same procedure of La. The pure product was obtained by crystallization from pentane solution. Yield: 3.52 g, 65%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 0.98 (s, 9H, -C(CH3)3), 1.15 (d, 24H, J = 6.9 Hz, −CH3), 1.22 (d, 12H, J = 6.9 Hz, −CH3), 2.85 (m, 2H, −CH), 3.79 (m, 4H, −CH), 3.82 (s, 4H, −CH2-), 5.63 (s, 1H, −OH), 6.54 (s, 2H, Ar-H), 6.97 (s, 4H, Ar-H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): 24.08, 24.59, 31.38, 31.66, 33.82, 34.43, 37.83, 121.89, 124.05, 126.83, 127.28, 142.60, 149.88, 150.25, 153.43. Mass spectrum: 669.4148 m/z (MNa+, calc: 669.4134), 1315.8441 m/z (M2Na+, calc. 1315.8376). Elemental Analysis: calcd.(%) for C42H62OS2: C, 77.96; H, 9.66; S, 9.91; found: C, 77.94; H, 9.68; S, 9.86. 2.5 Synthesis of the iron(II) complex 1a Pro-ligand La (502.6 mg; 1.11 mmol) was dissolved in THF (40 mL). The solution was added to a suspension of sodium hydride (30.6 mg; 1.28 mmol) in THF (10 mL) and the mixture stirred at room temperature overnight. The resulting suspension was filtered through celite and slowly added at room temperature to 137.2 mg of anhydrous iron(II) chloride (1.08 mmol) dissolved in 40 mL of THF. The reaction was kept overnight. The mixture was then filtered through celite and the solvent removed under reduced pressure. The solid was washed with hexane and dried in vacuum, affording a gray solid. Yield: 0.41 g, 65%. Elemental Analysis: calcd.(%) for C64H82Cl2Fe2O4S4: C, 62.69; H, 6.74; S, 10.46; found: C, 62.66; H, 6.76; S, 10.43. 2.6 Synthesis of the iron(II) complex 1b The complex 1b was synthesized using the same procedure of 1a. Yield: 0.43 g, 75%. Elemental Analysis: calcd.(%) for C56H58Cl10Fe2O4S4: C, 48.40; H, 4.21; S, 9.23; found: C, 48.38; H, 4.24; S, 9.19. 2.7 Synthesis of the iron(II) complex 1c The complex 1c was synthesized using the same procedure of 1a. Yield: 0.36 g, 64%. Elemental Analysis: calcd.(%) for C50H77ClFeO3S2: C, 68.12; H, 8.80; S, 7.27; found: C, 68.11; H, 8.82; S,7.25. 2.8 Synthesis of the iron(III) complex 2a Pro-ligand La (505.2 g; 1.12 mmol) was dissolved in THF (40 mL). The solution was added to a suspension of sodium hydride (30.6 mg; 1.28 mmol) in THF (10 mL) and the mixture stirred at room temperature overnight. The resulting suspension was filtered through celite and slowly added at room temperature to 177.2 mg of anhydrous iron(III) chloride (1.09 mmol) dissolved in 40 mL of THF. The reaction was kept overnight. The mixture was then filtered through celite and the solvent removed under reduced pressure. The solid was washed with hexane and dried in vacuum, affording a dark solid. Yield: 0.47 g, 75%. Elemental Analysis: calcd.(%) for C64H82Cl4Fe2O4S4: C, 59.26; H, 6.37; S, 9.89; found: C, 59.22; H, 6.40; S, 9.86. 2.9 Synthesis of the iron(III) complex 2b The complex 2b was synthesized using the same procedure of 2a. Yield: 0.52 g, 85%. Elemental Analysis: calcd.(%) for C28H29Cl6FeO2S2: C, 46.05; H, 4.00; S, 8.78; found: C, 46.04; H, 4.02; S, 8.74. 2.10 Synthesis of the iron(III) complex 2c The complex 2c was synthesized using the same procedure of 2a. Yield: 0.44 g, 75%. Analysis: calcd.(%) for C46H69Cl2FeO2S2: C, 65.39; H, 8.23; S, 7.59; found: C, 65.42; H, 8.25; S, 7.62. 2.11 Typical procedure for CO2/epoxide coupling to cyclic carbonates catalyzed by 1a/TBAB (entry S10, Table S1 in the Supporting information) A 60-mL stainless steel pressure reactor equipped with a magnetic stirring bar was charged, under CO2 atmosphere, with 13.5 mg of catalyst 1a (2.49 ∙ 10−5 mol) and 40.1 mg of TBAB (1.25 ∙ 10−4 mol) dissolved in 3.0 mL of HO (2.49 ∙ 10−2·mol). The reaction mixture was pressurized with CO2 at 1.0 MPa and stirred at 90 °C for 24 h. The reactor was cooled with ice, the CO2 released, 346 μL of mesitylene (2.49 ∙ 10−3 mol) was added as an internal standard and the mixture was analysed by 1H NMR spectroscopy using CDCl3 as solvent; yield: 87%. 2.12 UV–vis measurements The UV–vis spectra of the complexes were recorded in dichloromethane solutions, using a total concentration of iron equal to 0.1 mM. A typical procedure is reported for the case of complex 1a: three stock solutions were prepared dissolving 5.0 mg of 1a (2.04 mM), 5.0 mg of Pyr-d5 (14.86 mM) and 10.0 mg of TBAB (3.88 mM) in 4 mL of dichloromethane. The spectra were recorded using three different solution prepared using the following quantities: The spectrum of the complex 1a was recorded using a solution prepared diluting 49 μL of the 1a stock solution to a total volume of 1.0 mL ([Fe] = 0.1 mM). The spectrum of the complex 1a in presence of pyridine was recorded using a solution prepared diluting 49 μL of the 1a stock solution plus 336 μL of the Pyr-d5 stock solution, to a total volume of 1.0 mL ([Fe] = 0.1 mM; [Pyr] = 5 mM). solution to a total volume of 1.0 mL ([Fe] = 0.1 mM). The spectrum of the complex 1a in presence of TBAB was recorded using a solution prepared diluting 49 μL of the 1a stock solution plus 129 μL of the TBAB stock solution, to a total volume of 1.0 mL ([Fe] = 0.1 mM; [TBAB] = 0.5 mM). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of pro-ligands and complexes The three new monoanionic tridentate [SOS]-type bis-thioether-phenolate ligands La–c have been synthesized by reaction of the appropriate mercaptophenol a-c with 0.5 equivalent of the 2,6-bis-bromomethyl-4-tetr-butyl-phenol d (Scheme 1 ). The reaction procedure is similar to that reported in the case of the bis-thioether-tri-phenolate trianionic pentadentate ligands [35]. All the products have been isolated in good yield (from 65 to 80%) by crystallization from acetonitrile or pentane solutions, and characterised by NMR and HR-ESI-MS (Figs. S1–S9 in the supporting information). For each of the ligands, the corresponding Fe(II) (1a-c) and Fe(III) (2a-c) complexes were prepared reacting the sodium salt of the ligand with FeCl2 or FeCl3 in THF solution (Scheme 1). The products have been characterised by elemental analysis and UV–vis spectroscopy (Figs. 3 and S16). Attempts to record the 1H NMR spectra of the Fe(II) complexes 1a-c, in the spectral window from -200 to 200 ppm, were not successful. The effective magnetic moments μeff of all the Fe(II) and Fe(III) complexes, in CD2Cl2 solutions at 30 °C, were determined by means of the Evans method using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as internal standard. In order to obtain more information about the nature of the species in solution, the 1H NMR experiment was repeated for each complex before and after the addition of a large excess (50 equivalents) of deuterated pyridine (Pyr-d 5 ). The results are listed in Table 1 . Typical values of μeff of HS Fe(II) centres were observed for complex 1c (4.95 and 5.48 μB) [39,40], before and after the addition of pyridine. Lower values were obtained in the case of the less encumbered methyl and chlorine substituted complexes 1a and 1b (3.48 and 2.67 μB). However, after the addition of pyridine, the magnetic moments increased up to 5.67 and 4.83 μB, respectively. This behaviour can be explained with the formation of a dimeric structure in the native form of 1a and 1b, in which an antiferromagnetic coupling of the two HS Fe(II) centres is responsible of the low observed values. A similar dimeric-monomeric structure conversion was reported by Kleij et al. for a group of Fe(III) complexes bearing amino-triphenolate ligands [27]. Even in that case a variation of the magnetic moments in solution was observed, after the addition of pyridine, due to the breaking of a dimeric structure. In the case of the Fe(III) complexes 2a-c, the variation of the magnetic moment was observed only in the case of the methyl substituted complex 2a (from 2.49 to 4.72 μB). It is worth noting that, as a consequence of the addition of pyridine to the solution, the signals of free THF (at 1.90 and 3.80 ppm) appeared in all the spectra, indicating that THF is present in the coordination sphere of the complexes (Figs. S10–S15 in the SI). Therefore, one can suppose that for complexes 1a, 1b and 2a the presence of pyridine induces the breaking of the dimeric structures formed in THF during the synthesis, while for all the others it only replaces THF in the coordination sphere of the metal centre. On the basis of these considerations, the structures showed in Fig. 1 are proposed. 3.2 Catalytic activity in the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides The cycloaddition reaction of CO2 to 1,2-epoxyhexane (HO), without solvent, in the presence of 1a was selected as benchmark to find the best reaction conditions. As first, the reaction was performed, at 50 °C, 1.0 MPa of CO2 pressure and 0.1 mol% of 1a, using 0.1 mol% of different co-catalysts: dimetylaminopyridine (DMAP), bis-(triphenylphosphine)iminium chloride ([PPN]Cl), four tetrabutylammonium salts: azide (TBAN3), chloride (TBAC), iodide (TBAI) and bromide (TBAB). The catalytic activity was determined on the basis of the conversion of HO to the corresponding hexene carbonate (HC) after 24 h. The results are listed in Table S1 and summarized in Fig. 2 . In the case of DMAP, the HC formation was negligible (entry S1, Table S1), while the reaction proceeds faster in the presence of the halide and azide salts (entry S2-6, Table S1). The best performance was obtained in the presence of TBAB, with a TON of 110 (Fig. 2a). This observation is in line with our previous studies on the Fe(III)-mediated COCs formation, in which the presence of an nucleophilic anion is essential for the proceeding of the reaction [33–36]. An enhancement of the TON to 185 was obtained increasing the amount of TBAB up to 0.5 mol%, according with the reaction mechanism proposed in this study in which the bromide anion is involved in the ring opening of the epoxide (vide infra). Further increasing the TBAB concentration to 1 mol% does not affect the course of the reaction. The effect of the reaction temperature was also investigated (Fig. 2b). Passing from 50 to 70 °C the TON increases moderately. A strong effect on the catalytic activity was observed at 90 °C, reaching a TON of 870. A similar behaviour was observed in many cases [8–11]. Finally, all the Fe(II) and Fe(III) complexes were tested under the same reaction conditions (Table 2 ). At a first glance, it appears evident that, on the basis of the oxidation state of the iron centre, the catalytic activity is differently influenced by the nature of the ligand structure. More into details, the most active of the Fe(II) species was the methyl substituted complex 1a, with a TOF of 36 h−1 (entry 1, Table 2). The substitution of the methyl groups with electron withdrawing chlorine atoms, in the complex 1b, or with bulkier iso-propyl groups, in the complex 1c, has a detrimental effect on the TON (entries 2 and 3, Table 2). These variations can be reasonably explained on the basis of the results found in the case of the previously reported bis-thioether-tri-phenolate Fe(III) complexes. In that case, indeed, the presence of the chlorine atoms results in a strengthening of the S–Fe bond, reducing the Lewis acidity of the metal centre, while the increased steric hindrance around the catalyst probably renders the coordination of the epoxide to the metal centre less favourable [34]. Differently, for the Fe(III) complexes 2a-c, no dependence of the catalytic activity from the ligand structure was observed, with all of them showing similar TOF values of 31-32 h−1 (entries 4–6, Table 2). Notably the catalytic activity was the same even in the case of the complex 2a, that was found to exist in solution as a dimer. A similar invariance of the catalytic activity from the ligand structure, for the cycloaddition of CO2 to HO, was observed also in the case of the [OSSO]-type Fe(III) complexes, for which a bimetallic mechanism was demonstrated, involving the in situ formation of a metallate species from the reaction between the complexes and the co-catalyst [35]. To obtain deeper insights on the catalytic active species, the UV–vis spectra of the complexes 1a and 2a were recorded before and after the addition 50 equivalents of pyridine and 5 equivalents of TBAB with respect to iron (Fig. 3 ). The presence of pyridine in the solution changes the spectra profiles for both the complexes 1a and 2a, increasing the absorption at 350 and 347 nm respectively, indicating the breaking of the dimeric structures and in accordance with the variation of the effective magnetic moments reported in Table 1. A similar variation in the UV–vis spectrum of a dimeric iron species, after the addition of pyridine to the solution, was previously reported for an aminotriphenolate complex [27]. The presence of TBAB in solution has a different effect on the two complexes. In the case of the Fe(II) complex 1a, any appreciable variation in the adsorption spectrum was detected. On the contrary, in the case of the Fe(III) complex 2a, the interaction with TBAB results in an attenuation of the absorption band, with a red shift to 358 nm. The effect of the presence of TBAB on the UV–vis spectrum was evaluated for all the other complexes, and a variation was observed only in the case of the Fe(III) complexes 2b-c (Fig. S16). The same variation in the UV–vis spectra of Fe(III) species in the presence of TBAB, has been observed in the case of the [OSSO]-Fe(III) complexes, and explained with the formation of a new anionic species [36]. Accordingly, this interaction can be ascribed to the breaking of the dimer of 2a in concomitance with the formation of an anionic compound [2a-Br3]− , deriving from the reaction of the complex 2a with TBAB (Scheme 2 ). On the basis of the results described above, it appears that the oxidation state of the iron centre plays a prominent role in the determination of the catalytic activity. Indeed, in the case of the Fe(II) complexes 1a-c, the highest activity was observed for the less encumbered catalyst 1a. The chlorine substituted complex 1b and the iso-propyl substituted 1c were found to be much less reactive, with the catalytic site influenced by the electronic and steric properties of the ligand. In the case of the Fe(III) complexes 2a-c, TOFs near to that recorded for 1a were observed in all cases, because the bromide anion of TBAB was transferred to the metal centres with the in situ formation an anionic monomeric species, even in the case of the dimeric complex 2a. From the comparison of the systems discussed in this study, in which the effect of the oxidation state of the iron centre was investigated under the same coordination environment and reaction conditions, and in analogy with our previous studies on sulphur containing ligand based iron(III) systems [35,36], two different reaction mechanisms are suggested. In particular for the Fe(II) complexes 1a-c, we propose a monometallic reaction pathway in which the epoxide coordinates to the metal centre and the ring opening of the epoxy-ring involves a bromide anion provided from the co-catalyst (Fig. 4 ). For the Fe(III) complexes 2a-c, a bimetallic reaction pathway is proposed (Fig. 5 ), in which the formation of an anionic species occurs in the reaction medium (Scheme 2). In this anion, all the coordination sites are occupied. However the coordination of the epoxide is still possible because of the small concentration of iron used under the reaction conditions. The ring opening of the epoxide involves, in this case, a bromide anion deriving from the Fe metallate species, justifying the fact that the activity does not depends from the substitution on the ancillary ligand. Since the catalytic system 1a/TBAB resulted the most active in the formation of HC, it was tested in the reaction of carbon dioxide with other epoxides. The same reactions were also conducted using the Fe(III) complex 2a, bearing the same methyl substituted ligand, for comparison. The results are listed in Table 3 . High conversions of epichlorohydrin (EPC) were obtained in both cases in only 6 h, with a TOF of 155 h−1 (entries 1 and 2 Table 3). The higher reactivity of EPC observed in this case, with respect to HO, is in line with our previous studies on the Fe-promoted cycloaddition reaction [33–36]. Good activity were observed also for allyl glycidyl ether and the bio-surced furfuryl glycidyl ether, obtaining high conversion in 16 h (entries 3–6 Table 3). Activities comparable with that of HO, were observed in the case of the formation of styrene carbonate (entries 7 and 8 Table 3). In the same conditions, even the less reative cyclohexene oxide is converted with appreciable activities (entries 9 and 10 Table 3). In this case, a total selectivity toward the formation of cis−CHC was achieved. 4 Conclusion We have described the synthesis and characterization of three new bis-thioether phenolate ligands (La-c), and of the corresponding Fe(II) (1a-c) and Fe(III) (2a-c) complexes. The formation of monomeric or dimeric structures depending on the ligand steric bulk was confirmed by effective magnetic moments measurements in CD2Cl2 solutions. When activated by TBAB, all the complexes resulted active in the cycloaddition of CO2 to various epoxides with good activity. Insights into the reaction mechanism were obtained by studying the reaction between the catalyst precursor and TBAB by means of UV–vis experiments revealing the formation of a metallate anionic species only in the case of the Fe(III) complexes. The formation of this species is crucial for the observed catalytic activity in the coupling of CO2 with epoxides and also explain the different behaviour of the Fe(II) complexes with respect to the Fe(III) complexes. Coherently a different mechanistic scenario is proposed depending on the oxidation state of the catalyst precursor. For the first time the effect of the oxidation state, for a given ligand environment, has been evidenced in the case of iron-based catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. The authors are also grateful to Dr. Patrizia Oliva and Dr. Patrizia Iannece from University of Salerno for technical assistance. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis and characterization of three new bis-thioether-phenolate monoanionic tridentate [SOS]-type ligands, and the synthesis of the corresponding Fe(II) and Fe(III) complexes are reported. Their application, in combination with tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB), as catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 to a number of monosubstituted epoxides and cyclohexene oxide was investigated. For example, epichlorohydrin is converted in the corresponding cyclic carbonate, with a turnover frequency of 155 h−1 (0.1 mol% of iron, 0.5 mol% of TBAB, 10 bar of CO2). With the aim to obtain further information about the catalyst structure-activity relationship and the reaction mechanism, the reaction between the catalyst precursors and TBAB was investigated, suggesting the formation of an anionic metallate species in the case of the Fe(III) complexes that is supposed to be true catalyst. A mechanistic scenario explaining the different behaviour of the Fe(II) and Fe(III) complexes is proposed.
coredata.dc:title: CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides promoted by bis-thioether-phenolate Fe(II) and Fe(III) complexes
